SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Feeling out of sorts, fatigue, and lightheadedness.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He denies fever, chills, or shortness of breath but reports occasional slight chest cramps that resolve within an hour. He has a slight cough, which he attributes to the change of seasons. The patient admits to struggling with his diet due to recent home renovations, leading to eating out more frequently. He is compliant with his medications and monitors his blood pressure regularly.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Occasional slight chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Slight cough.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: Jugular venous distention to about 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Within normal limits.
• Heart Rate: Within normal limits.
• Oxygenation: Within normal limits.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in the lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive Heart Failure:
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by the physical exam and chest X-ray.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath.
• Additional Testing: Order another echocardiogram.

Hypertension:
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue with Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents with right knee pain following a fall from a ladder while changing a light bulb yesterday. She reports twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The pain is located on the inside of her knee. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but these measures have provided minimal relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

MEDICATIONS

Digoxin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right knee pain.
• Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the medial portion of the right knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress. Normal sensation in the lower extremity.
• Neurological: Normal sensation in the lower extremity.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right knee demonstrates no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents with right knee pain following a fall.

Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's history and physical examination findings are consistent with an acute medial meniscus sprain or strain.
• Medical Treatment: We will provide a knee brace and crutches for temporary use. The patient will return in one week for reevaluation. If there is no improvement, we will consider ordering an MRI.
• Medications: Prescribe Motrin 800 mg every six hours with food for two weeks.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Lower back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. He presents today with lower back pain after lifting heavy boxes too quickly on Saturday. He reports hearing a pop and experiencing pain, which has persisted since the incident. The patient has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and Icy Hot, but these have not provided significant relief. He also experienced tingling in his right toes, which resolved on Sunday.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur (stable).
• Musculoskeletal: Lower back pain with flexion and extension, pain to palpation of lumbar spine, negative straight leg raise.
• Endocrine: Diabetes type 2.
• Vascular: Hypertension.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

Back X-ray: Normal, good bony alignment, no fracture present.

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lumbar strain:
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Refer to physical therapy.

2. Diabetes type 2:
   • Medical Reasoning: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated, indicating poor control.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day, repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

3. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are on the high side.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

4. Osteoarthritis:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is monitoring knee and no further workup is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports managing his depression well with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He has been struggling with hypertension, but his blood pressure has improved. He experiences shortness of breath with exertion during his morning runs. The patient also reports nasal congestion due to pollen.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, managed with Prozac.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• ENT: Endorses nasal congestion.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• ENT: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.

Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing well with Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription ordered.

2. Prior lobectomy
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is exercising regularly, and his breathing function is fine.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed at this time.

3. Hypertension
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure has improved, but he occasionally forgets to take his medication on weekends.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication (Norvasc). Encourage adherence to medication schedule.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the murmur.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up through the patient portal for the results of the echocardiogram and routine blood work.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain. She states she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her ski strap caught on her finger, bending it back. The incident occurred on Sunday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but the pain persists. She rates her pain as severe with movement. She has a history of constipation and takes Miralax. She had her appendix removed when she was 18. She denies any allergies.

EXAM

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx and pain with flexion. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Patient is able to bend and extend the finger and touch her thumb with it.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and normal alignment.

IMPRESSION

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we provide her with an aluminum foam splint and prescribe Motrin, 600 mg, to take every 6 hours for a week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and schedule a follow-up appointment. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a past medical history significant for iron deficiency anemia, anxiety, and depression. She presents today after being unable to donate blood due to her anemia. She has been dealing with anemia since she was 13 years old. The patient reports feeling fatigued, feverish with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also experiences cold intolerance and worsening anxiety and depression.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, fever, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.
• Psychiatric: Endorses worsening anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended. No rebound or guarding.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a past medical history significant for iron deficiency anemia, anxiety, and depression, who presents today with ongoing anemia.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: She has a long-standing history of anemia, and her recent blood work revealed low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, normal iron labs, and low ferritin.
• Additional Testing: Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Medical Treatment: Continue taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 8-12 weeks.
• Referral: Sent referral to hematologist for further evaluation and management.

Anxiety and depression.
• Medical Reasoning: Patient reports worsening anxiety and depression.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current treatment and monitor for changes.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with no significant past medical history, who presents with worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches in the past. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for a neurosurgical consultation due to the incidental discovery of a pituitary lesion during the workup for his headaches.

The patient describes the headaches as a dull, nagging ache located behind his eyes. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago, and has been worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. He denies any associated symptoms such as fever, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he reports bumping into door frames recently.

MRI of the brain with contrast reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results being normal.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss.
• Neurological: Positive for headaches, denies numbness or tingling.
• Ophthalmologic: Denies vision changes, endorses bumping into door frames.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent.
• Cranial Nerve: Examination is grossly intact.
• Motor and Sensory: No focal deficits in the upper or lower extremities.
• Ophthalmologic: Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with an incidental pituitary lesion discovered during the workup for worsening headaches.

Pituitary Adenoma.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression due to the pituitary lesion.
• Surgical Intervention: Transsphenoidal approach to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa is indicated. The patient has been informed of the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery.
• Additional Testing: Refer the patient for a visual field test and ophthalmologic evaluation before and after surgery to monitor changes in peripheral vision.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended surgical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids and anemia. She presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient experienced chest pain and difficulty swallowing for four days in early October 2020. The chest pain was located in the center of her chest, behind the breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The pain was worse with eating. The patient visited the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, which were normal. The patient has not had any chest pain or difficulty swallowing since the initial episode.

The patient has a history of gallbladder removal several years ago. She denies any family history of GI problems. She was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the chest pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower abdomen.

RESULTS

EKG and blood tests from the ER visit were normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Betty Hill is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids and anemia. She presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis.

Possible etiologies:
• GERD
• Dyspepsia
• Esophagitis
• Musculoskeletal etiologies
• Anxiety

Suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, plus or minus a contribution from her musculoskeletal etiologies.

Plan:
• Discussed the option of EGD vs. monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT:

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a former 34 and 3-week-old twin. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. The patient has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned potential kidney issues related to her syndrome.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:

• Constitutional: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:

• General Examination: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. Several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature.

We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a patient who presents with right wrist pain after falling on stairs while doing laundry. She reports significant swelling and pain, rating it as a 9 out of 10. She has tried ice, an ace wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She denies any previous injuries to the arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematemesis, hematochezia, melena, heartburn, or abdominal pain.
• Genitourinary: Denies urinary urgency, pain, or incontinence.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right wrist pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Musculoskeletal: Obvious swelling and bruising of the right wrist. Pain on palpation, flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Bony crepitus noted.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist: Positive for a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Diana presents with a Colles' fracture of the right wrist after a fall.

• Medical Treatment: Initiate Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours for pain management.
• Orthopedic Intervention: Schedule surgery for fracture repair and stabilization.
• Postoperative Care: Provide a brace for the wrist, to be worn for approximately 6 weeks.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for postoperative rehabilitation, to begin a few weeks after surgery.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Discuss the need for surgery and potential postponement of vacation plans. Schedule a follow-up appointment in one month to assess progress and determine if vacation is feasible.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a 59-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension, who presents today with right knee pain. The patient reports that he slipped and fell while working on his property a week ago. He felt something pop in his knee and has been experiencing pain, particularly during flexion and extension. He has been taking ibuprofen for pain and swelling. The patient rates his pain as 4 out of 10 when moving his knee. He also has a history of hypertension and is currently taking 20 mg of Lisinopril daily. He admits to not making significant changes to his diet as previously discussed.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
• Respiratory: No shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain and swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee, pain with flexion and extension, edema around the knee, and effusion present.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Elevated at 150/70 mmHg.

RESULTS

Right knee X-ray: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times a day.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Advise the patient to elevate and rest the affected leg.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is taking Lisinopril 20 mg daily but has not made significant changes to his diet.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   • Additional Testing: Referral to nutrition for dietary management and support.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a middle-aged male who presents with left shoulder pain for approximately three weeks. The patient is unable to recall any specific injury but has been active and recently working on renovating his basement. He reports difficulty reaching for objects, lifting, and lying on the affected shoulder. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure. He has been taking extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which provides some relief but does not eliminate the pain.

PAST HISTORY

No significant past medical history.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Left shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.

Neurovascular exam of the left arm: Capillary refill less than three seconds, sensation intact to light touch.

RESULTS
Imaging

Left shoulder X-ray: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

1. Order MRI of the left shoulder to further evaluate the rotator cuff and rule out other causes of pain.
2. Refer the patient to physical therapy for six to eight weeks.
3. Continue Tylenol for pain management.
4. Consider steroid injection if symptoms do not improve after physical therapy.
5. Schedule follow-up appointment after completion of physical therapy.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow the physical therapy regimen and continue taking Tylenol as needed for pain. Schedule a follow-up appointment after completing physical therapy. Contact the clinic if pain worsens or new symptoms arise.

CC:

Left knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Andrea is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of left knee pain. She reports occasional knee pain that occurs less than once a day, usually while walking. The pain is described as internal and affecting the whole kneecap. The patient denies any history of injury to the knee or any recent trauma. She has not taken any medication for the pain as it does not last long. The patient is concerned about her upcoming trip, which will involve a lot of walking and dancing, and is considering not participating in certain activities due to her knee pain.

PMH:

Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus

MEDICATIONS:

Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, Metformin

EXAM:

Vital Signs: Temp 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, BP 122/70
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally
Left Knee: No ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation; full range of motion; negative varus and valgus test

RESULTS:

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Left knee pain - Suspect arthritis. Prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee and prevent further problems.

2. Hypertension - Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.

3. Diabetes Mellitus - Order Hemoglobin A1c to assess the need for adjustments to Metformin dosage. Also, order a lipid panel.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, cough, and sore throat.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending. She reports a minimal cough and sore throat today, with no shortness of breath. She has experienced some fatigue but no nausea or vomiting. She has good support from family, friends, and the nursing staff.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Respiratory: Dry cough, sore throat.
General: Fatigue.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Stable, oxygen saturation within normal limits.
Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Crackles bilaterally in lungs.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, likely related to radiation.
Lower extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
- Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion to assess for surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Abnormal lab work - low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 48-year-old male who presents for evaluation of a low immunoglobulin A level. The patient was referred by his primary care physician after a recent physical examination. The patient reports frequent colds during the winter months, which tend to linger for a long time. He denies any recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. He has a family history of type 2 diabetes and was recently diagnosed with the condition himself. He is currently taking metformin.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Vitals: Within normal limits, no fever.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Low immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Immunoglobulin A deficiency: The patient has a low immunoglobulin A level, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live their entire lives without any significant issues. The patient does not appear to have frequent respiratory tract, sinus, or abdominal infections. We will order additional blood work to check for other immunodeficiencies. The patient should be aware of this deficiency in case he needs blood products in the future.

2. Type 2 diabetes: The patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and is currently taking metformin. He should continue to monitor his blood sugar levels and follow up with his primary care physician for management.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should watch for any infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control. If any changes in his abdominal tract or severe diarrhea occur, he should seek medical attention. The patient should inform healthcare providers of his immunoglobulin A deficiency if he requires blood products. The patient will have additional blood work done to check for other immunodeficiencies.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a patient who presents with right elbow pain for the past 4 days. He reports that the pain started after engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. He rates the pain as a 6/10 and states that it interferes with his daily activities and sleep. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain and tenderness.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Musculoskeletal
- Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation on the medial epicondyle.
- Range of Motion: Pain with pronation of the forearm and resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

VITALS REVIEWED

Blood Pressure, Heart Rate, Respiratory Rate, and Temperature are within normal limits.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality detected.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right elbow pain.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with medial epicondylitis, likely due to overuse and potential damage to the tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the diagnosis and advised the patient to avoid pottery activities for the next couple of weeks.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribed a sling for the patient to wear while awake, instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day, and advised to take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week.
- Follow-up: Scheduled a follow-up appointment in one week to assess the patient's progress.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a patient who recently visited the emergency department due to chest pain and shortness of breath. He reports that he was outside walking when he experienced the symptoms and subsequently fell. He has a history of hypertension and has been prescribed Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc. He admits to missing his medications occasionally and not following a strict diet, consuming salty foods such as chips.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath.
• Neurological: No reported issues.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: No jugular venous distention.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable. Trace edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

David is a patient with a history of hypertension who presents with chest pain and shortness of breath.

Congestive heart failure exacerbation:
• Medical Reasoning: Likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily. Consult with a nutritionist for dietary advice.
• Patient Monitoring: Weigh daily and call if a weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days occurs.

Hypertension management:
• Medical Reasoning: Uncontrolled hypertension contributing to CHF exacerbation.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg daily.
• Additional Testing: Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out other causes.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain, but it has not been effective. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Kidney stones.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Not provided.

FAMILY HISTORY

Father: Kidney stones.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Tylenol.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdominal exam: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA tenderness: Positive on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain, alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide urine strainer for stone collection.
4. Order basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks to assess symptoms and discuss further treatment options, such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy, if necessary.
6. Instruct patient to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a nonhealing foot ulcer on his right foot. The patient first noticed the ulcer approximately six weeks ago after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The initial blister has since become unroofed, revealing soft, mushy skin with a foul smell and yellow drainage. The patient's wife called their primary care doctor, who started the patient on antibiotics six days ago. The patient has experienced some chills and a fever of 99.7°F, but no nausea or vomiting. The wound has turned black around the edges, and the patient has been experiencing cramping in his calf muscle. There is also a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is very hot.

The patient's blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range over the past two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His most recent A1c is 6.7.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

RESULTS

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.
   - Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
   - Perform debridement in the office today.
   - Obtain a culture and consider different antibiotic therapy depending on the results.
   - Monitor the redness and swelling in the patient's calf.
   - Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.

2. Diabetes management.
   - Encourage the patient to follow up with their endocrinologist.
   - Aim to keep the patient's hemoglobin A1c below 7.
   - Closely monitor blood sugars during medication therapy.

INSTRUCTIONS

- Continue the current antibiotic therapy as prescribed by the primary care doctor.
- Follow up with the endocrinologist for diabetes management.
- Return in 7 days for a follow-up appointment, or sooner if needed.
- Call with any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes who presents today with a tick bite on his right knee. The patient is unsure where he got the tick bite but has been spending time outdoors, including hunting recently. The tick bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. The patient denies fever or chills but has been experiencing a headache and general malaise since the tick bite. He has no difficulty moving his knee or walking and has not experienced any other joint pain.

The patient reports that his blood pressure has been well-controlled with lisinopril and his blood sugars have been running in the 120s with metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: No palpitations.
• Respiratory: No shortness of breath or cough.
• Musculoskeletal: No joint pain other than typical arthritic pain.
• Integumentary: Tick bite on right knee.
• Psychiatric: No depression or anxiety.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: BP 122/70, HR 67, Temp 98.4°F.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, rub, or gallop.
• Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee, pain to palpation of right anterior knee.
• Integumentary: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella, bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.
   - Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 3 weeks.
   - Order Lyme titer and Western blot.
   - Monitor for any worsening symptoms or signs of systemic involvement.

2. Hypertension.
   - Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day.
   - Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
   - Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day.
   - Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
   - Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

- Take medications as prescribed.
- Monitor tick bite and report any worsening symptoms or new symptoms.
- Return for follow-up as needed or if any concerns arise.
